posts.cooked:
These past few weeks, Iâ€™ve been working on a project where I try to simulate the motion of mechanisms in FRC using feedforward gains. So far, Iâ€™ve only been testing using motors with no load, and there will probably be other problems when load is introduced, but I am running into something else right now.

The code I have (linked below) works well for tracking velocities and positions of motors most of the time. So far Iâ€™ve only used a neo and a kraken. However, when the voltage is set to 0, the simulation becomes very inaccurate, since the only thing acting on the motor shaft at that point is friction. I was wondering what solutions I could try to model this case.

Github link for the code: GitHub - VimalBuckley/MotorSim Image of real neo velocity (red) vs simulated (blue): image 2559Ã—1165 109 KB

image 2559Ã—1165 109 KB

image 2559Ã—1165 109 KB

Link to wpilog with the code from github being run: log.zip (80.5 KB) The log contains data from a physical kraken and neo, as well as from a simulated kraken and neo.

Any advice would be appreciated, thanks!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
0 volt behavior heavily depends on if your motor is in brake or coast mode.

What mode are you trying to model, or rather, what mode were these NEOs in when you measured?

The neo was in brake mode

EDIT: I WAS WRONG The neo was in coast mode. Changing to brake mode leads to much better tracking

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: Youâ€™ll get more realistic results at zero volts if you use a simulation with some sort of mass/inertia modeled. The flywheelsim and elevatorsim classes in wpilib are good examples

Yeah Iâ€™ve looked at them. They are probably a lot more accurate then my simulation. This has been more of a project for fun and my own curiosity. I just felt like it should be possible to model this only using feedforward constants, but maybe it isnâ€™t.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Iâ€™m skeptical that thatâ€™s the problem here, as the acceleration is tracking well, itâ€™s only when decelerating specifically to 0 volts that it seems thereâ€™s a discrepancy. I felt like it must be that the motor is in coast mode while the feed-forward calculations model brake mode, but apparently thatâ€™s not the case.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
I am thinking rater than the manipulation of voltage being fed into the motor, you should consider the status of your mechanism rather than manipulating voltage for a more realistic result and in real world programming, you could use these status commands to make your code easier to impliment.

That is, think your motor could have these following status:

Disabled, break

Disabled, coast

Enabled, break

Enabled, set RPM to x

Enabled, set potision to x degree

In conjunction with Motion Profiling , this is something that you would want to use on a real robot.

link_counts.title: Motion Profiling through TrapezoidProfileSubsystems and TrapezoidProfileCommands â€” FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: I just realized that I had misremembered the idle mode of the motor. The NEO was actually in coast mode, and switching it to brake does make it track very well. Thank you so much, and sorry for the confusion!
